noBirdsInCollection: No birds have been added to the encyclopedia yet.
stellersSeaEagle:
Steller's Sea Eagle is one of the largest eagles in the world.
It is very powerful and flies with large wings.
Born in Russia, it comes to Hokkaido, Japan in winter.

It is also called "Steller's Eagle" after the scholar who discovered it.
Its numbers are decreasing and it is designated as an endangered species.

GB saw enough for a lifetime in Rausu in winter,
but it was so cool that I want to see it again.
komadori:
The Japanese Robin is one of Japan's three most famous singing birds, measuring about 14 cm in length.
It inhabits mountain forests and is omnivorous, eating insects and nuts.

It is very wary and difficult to spot,
but it sings with a beautiful voice resembling a horse's neigh, "Hin-kara-kara-kara-kara." Males have a black band on their chests.

It often appears in many literary and artistic works as a bird symbolizing the arrival of spring.
whiteTailedEagle:
White-tailed eagles migrate to Japan in October, and some that breed in Hokkaido leave for their breeding grounds in March.

They mainly feed on fish, but also prey on birds, rabbits, and snakes, and eat carrion.

In Hokkaido, they nest in large trees, laying 1 to 3 eggs per clutch. Both sexes incubate for about one month, and the chicks fledge about two months after hatching.

When I went to eastern Hokkaido, they were everywhere like crows.
sparrow:
While sparrows eat rice, they also eat harmful insects,
so they have long been recognized as beneficial birds.

They appear in old tales and children's songs,
and have been a familiar and beloved presence to Japanese people.
However, they are very wary and do not easily get used to humans.

They take water baths and sand baths to keep their feathers clean.
rockPtarmigan:
The Rock Ptarmigan is a pheasant-like bird.
Chickens are also pheasant-like birds.
Like chickens, ptarmigans love plants.

However, their rarity is on a completely different level!!
When GauraBirder went to Tateyama, they lived like free-spirited ladies,
not afraid of humans.
They know that everyone is kind to them.

Japanese ptarmigans live in high mountain areas above 2,300m,
and are rare birds whose feather color changes drastically three times a year.
blakistonsFishOwl:
Blakiston's Fish Owl, one of the largest owls in the world,
inhabits only Hokkaido and the Northern Territories in Japan.

Blakiston's Fish Owl is called "the guardian deity of the village" by the Ainu people.
Currently, over 100 pairs have been confirmed mainly in the eastern Hokkaido region,
but their habitat is limited to a part of Hokkaido,
and they are still on the verge of extinction.

Their Ainu name [Kotankor Kamuy] means [god who owns the village].
redCrownedCrane:
The name "Tancho" (Red-crowned crane) comes from the red part on its crown.
Its redness increases when it gets excited.

It is one of 15 species of cranes in the world,
and the only crane that breeds in Japan.
Japan's largest wild bird: It is Japan's largest wild bird, with a total length of about 140 cm and a wingspan of 220 to 250 cm.

Once a pair forms, they stay together for life,
and are considered a symbol of marital harmony.
In their "calling," the male's voice is "Koh!" and the female's voice is "Kak-kak!".
whooperSwan:
Whooper swans migrate to Japan as winter birds,
and mainly winter in Hokkaido and northern Tohoku.
Among Japanese wild birds, they are particularly heavy,
with some individuals weighing over 10 kg.
Because their wings are small for their weight,
they need to keep flapping their wings while flying.

Once a pair forms, they live with the same partner for life,
and are birds with very strong family bonds.
In Ainu language, they are called "Retatchiri Kamuy," meaning "white bird god."

The protagonist of Hans Christian Andersen's "The Ugly Duckling" is a swan,
which is gray when it is young,
but grows into a beautiful white bird.
